article:
'Kyle Minor' (born 1976) is an American writer. Born and raised in Florida,
Minor lived in Indiana and Kentucky before settling in Ohio. He studied writing
at The Ohio State University, where he was a three-time honoree in The Atlantic
Monthly Student Writing Awards and a winner of the 2012 Iowa Review Prize for
Short Fiction and Random House's Twentysomething Essays by Twentysomething
Writers contest, and at the Iowa Writers' Workshop.

Minor has taught creative writing and literature at various schools, including
The Ohio State University, The University of Toledo, Capital University, and
Gotham Writers Workshop. He is currently working on a novel and a work of
narrative nonfiction, both set in the Haitian countryside.

His debut collection of short fiction, In the Devil's Territory, included the
novella A Day Meant to Do Less, which was chosen by George Pelecanos for
Houghton Mifflin's Best American Mystery Stories 2008 anthology. His stories and
essays also appear in literary journals including [[Esquire
(magazine)|Esquire]], [[Southern Review]], [[Gettysburg Review]], and Gulf
Coast, and he writes a biweekly column for Salon.com.
